docs.lead_paragraph: In a secular society, religious freedom demands respect and accommodation, not veto power over government actions.

headline.main: The Fallacy of the Latest Contraception Case
headline.print_headline: The Fallacy of the Latest Contraception Case

docs.abstract: Editorial examines latest challenge to Affordable Care Act to reach Supreme Court, which centers on whether several religious schools and order of Catholic nuns must complete form notifying government of their refusal to provide employees with insurance coverage for birth control; suggests decision in case should be easy, given that right to religious freedom does not grant individuals or institutions veto power over laws they disagree with.
docs.snippet: In a secular society, religious freedom demands respect and accommodation, not veto power over government actions.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Some New Yorkers who have the company’s health insurance policies said they were worried how they would pay medical expenses next month, after Health Republic closes on Nov. 30.

headline.main: New Yorkers Face Hard Decisions After Collapse of Health Republic Insurance
headline.print_headline: New Yorkers Face Difficult Decisions After an Insurer’s Sudden Collapse

docs.abstract: Collapse of Health Republic Insurance of New York, health care co-op purporting to offer alternative to government-run plans, has left 200,000 people scrambling for health care coverage; closing, driven by cuts to government subsidies, low premiums and rising costs, offers cautionary tale to other faltering insurers.
docs.snippet: Some New Yorkers who have the company’s health insurance policies said they were worried how they would pay medical expenses next month, after Health Republic closes on Nov. 30.

docs.lead_paragraph: That way, said Matt Bevin, the incoming Republican governor, an objection by same-sex marriage opponents would be removed.

headline.main: Governor-Elect Pledges to Take Clerks’ Names Off Kentucky Licenses
headline.print_headline: Pledging to Take Clerks’ Names Off Kentucky Licenses

docs.abstract: Kentucky Gov-elect Matt Bevin says that once he takes office, he will order marriage licenses without county clerk names on them, means of addressing conservative complaint that clerks opposing same-sex marriage should not be forced to sign such licenses.
docs.snippet: That way, said Matt Bevin, the incoming Republican governor, an objection by same-sex marriage opponents would be removed.

docs.lead_paragraph: The case concerns nonprofit groups like schools and hospitals that are affiliated with religious organizations, and rules for insurance coverage for contraceptives.

headline.main: Supreme Court to Hear New Case on Contraception and Religion
headline.print_headline: Supreme Court to Hear Another Case on Contraception and Religion

docs.abstract: Supreme Court is set to hear case on whether nonprofit groups affiliated with religious organizations are required to pay health care coverage for employee birth control; case represents second time contraception requirement has been challenged and fourth time court has considered aspect of Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: The case concerns nonprofit groups like schools and hospitals that are affiliated with religious organizations, and rules for insurance coverage for contraceptives.

docs.lead_paragraph: Once enrolled in Medicare, H.S.A. holders cannot make new contributions to the savings plan. Careful planning is needed to maximize the savings.
docs.abstract: Ann Carrns Your Money Matters column says special rules apply to older people who contribute to tax-favored health savings accounts as they near age 65 and become eligible for federal Medicare coverage; questions and answers on health savings accounts given.
docs.snippet: Once enrolled in Medicare, H.S.A. holders cannot make new contributions to the savings plan. Careful planning is needed to maximize the savings.

docs.lead_paragraph: Veterans' hospitals and clinics are beefing up staff and seeing more patients, but the number of appointments not completed within 30 days continues to grow, Department of Veterans Affairs Robert McDonald said Friday.
